The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game
boardgamefamily: Lord of the Rings: The Card Game (LCG)

107934.description:
Game description from the publisher:

The Matriarchy Troop Pack for Tannhäuser further expands the Matriarchy faction by adding two stunningly painted miniatures – the fearless Boepripacy Soldat and the flamethrower-wielding Zazigag Soldat – along with game tokens, equipments cards, and a detailed 12-page rulebook with an all-new scenario.

This scenario pits a Nippon Accords force against an alliance of UMTOMA soldiers, as the Reich's Karl Zermann attempts to recover an ancient artifact for Von Heïzinger.
107934.name: Tannhäuser: Matriarchy Troop Pack

107935.description:
(note: this "upgrade pack" requires the base Puzzle Strike game to play)

Upgrade your puzzle striking with several new components to enhance aesthetics, immersion and accessibility as well as new puzzle chips and rebalanced character chips.

This upgrade pack includes:

4 identical playmats
4 unique screens to hide your chips without holding them in your hand
3 new puzzle chips x 5 copies each
15 blank chips
A rebalanced set of the 10 characters in the base set (30 character chips)




The playmats help you separate your gem pile and other game zones, plus they look great! They're made of the same high quality mouse pad material as the Yomi playmats, and you could even use them as mouse pads.

This upgrade pack is compatible with the second edition (pink boxed) version of Puzzle Strike, and not the first edition Deluxe with the wooden chips.
107935.name: Puzzle Strike Upgrade Pack
boardgamepodcastepisode: 28 Games Later: Puzzle Strike Upgrade!

107936.name: Dreamcast Collection
107936.description:
User Summary:

Dreamcast Collection is compilation of four games that were originally released on the SEGA Dreamcast.

-Sonic Adventure
-Crazy Taxi
-Sega Bass Fishing
-Space Channel 5: Part 2

107937.name: Map Exploring
107937.description:
User summary:
A tile-laying game for 2–4 players. Players have their starting point in one of the corners of a thought 7x7 tile map, with the goal in the middle. Taking turns of laying down tiles with straight corridors, bends, T-crossings and so on, some of which are one-way, the player who first connects his starting point with the goal wins the game. Among the special tiles are tiles that allow you to turn, move or remove an already laid tile.

107938.name: Dicecapades! Kerfuffle!
107938.description: Roll your dice and try to create a pair, three of a kind, four of a kind, etc., or a straight by lining up your dice with the dice already on the game grid. But, here's the catch... You need to do this while doing what the drawn card says! You might get lucky and only have to start your turn with a three of a kind. Or, you might have to "whistle while you work!" First player to get rid of all their dice wins in this LAUGH OUT LOUD strategy game for the whole family!

107939.name: Stellar Escape
107939.description:
A runner with acrobatic moves that requires a lot of skill, but is easy to get into. The task of running for your life has never been so intuitive and visually appealing. Get it from App Store or Android Market.

Source: The Developer Website.

107940.description:
In the abandoned and uncharted spaces of the solar system a small group of daredevil pilots fly their spacecraft through dangerous race courses known as Circuits. Set up in advance by a shadowy group of scouts and bookies, each Circuit is unique. Some wind through planetary canyons, others through old mining tunnels bored through asteroids or through the swirling rocks of planetary rings. Racers must dodge obstacles as well as the weapons fire of their opponents to cross the finish line first to win fame and fortune!

Solar Circuit Racing is a sci-fi racing game for 2-6 players. The game is played on a modular, customizable course made out of map tiles. Moving into a tile with an obstacle requires a piloting roll. Failing the piloting roll results in something bad happening, like smashing into an asteroid or scraping a wing along a canyon wall. Damage reduces the capabilities of your ship. Once you pass the roll, you can advance into the space and move on.

Each turn, you will have to manage your limited engine power, and make decisions about how to spend it. Engine power can be used to advance through the course, to evade enemy weapons, and to make maneuvering through obstacles easier. Spend too much power on maneuvering and your opponents will jump into the lead, too much on advancing and you'll splatter against the obstacles. The first player to complete the decided on number of laps wins.
107940.name: Solar Circuit Racing

107941.name: Air Cavalry
107941.description:
Air Cavalry is a flight simulation video game developed by Synergistic Software. It was released by Cybersoft and GameTek for the Super NES in 1995. In the game, the player controls an advanced helicopter gunship. Flying above multiple types of terrain, the players will complete a number of objectives using different types of helicopters with different uses for each. Players can select from three theatres of operations with six or more objectives that increase in difficulty. Players can also practice in the training mission.

Source: Wikipedia, "Air Cavalry (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

107942.name: TextTrain
107942.description:
From the Beagle Bros Winter 1980-81 catalog:

For all you ELECTRIC TRAIN fans, here's TextTrain! You completely control a text-format freight train on your Apple's video layout! Forward, reverse, track switches, coupling and uncoupling, the works! Switching and coupling strategies become critical as you are tmed by an on-screen clock while you attempt to couple together a pre-defined trainload of goods. A freight-On-Board chart consistently updates your cargo.

If you avoid a game ending collision and complete your assignment, your train will be inspected and your time recorded and posted for comparison on future tries. For one or more players, this one will keep you up till next Wednesday!

107943.name: Sub Search
107943.description:
From the Beagle Bros Winter 1980-81 catalog:

Find the invisible subs in your Apple color graphics scope before your oxygen and fuel run out! Use your deep-sea scanner switch and watch for the blips that give clues to each sub's whereabouts. A scan-tracer shows you where you have looked, and if you are unable to locate all subs, the computer reveals their locations in comparison to where you have searched. A final score printout lets you compare your success with others.

107944.name: Pick-a-Pair
107944.description:
From the Beagle Bros Winter 1980-81 catalog:

Pick-a-Pair is Beagle Bros' version of the old "concentration" matching game. Apple-filed and ready to play. match the symbols behind the numbers to score. Beeps, buzzes and players' names enhance the scorekeeping, and full-color graphics and no-return keyboard input makes this an easy-to-play, FUN-to-play computer game.

A great Apple demo game for non-computerers (you have noticed THEM, haven't you?).!

107945.name: Wowzo!
107945.description:
From the Beagle Bros Winter 1980-81 catalog:

Beagle Bros' real-time Apple maze game!

Each player moves his or her own name through a constantly-changing maze towards five targets. Maze gates are opened and closed through keyboard commands to gain access to targets or to strategically block an opponent. All moves are time-limited to keep the game moving. Player input the game clock's speed as well as their names, abilities and target information to make each game unique. Your Apple adds ts own touches with extensive sound effects, an animated clock and a constantly visible scoreboard. All move and gate commands are presented with player names and move/gate requests.

Wowzo is a strategy game you can grow with. Add it to your Apple library!

107946.name: Elevators
107946.description:
From the Beagle Bros Winter 1980-81 catalog:

You'll need a computer to conquer this one! Four elevators in a 12-story color graphics building. The object is to see how quickly and efficiently you can get rush-hour passengers to the first floor. A real-time keyboard challenge for one or two players!

107947.name: Quick-Draw!
107947.description:
From the Beagle Bros Winter 1980-81 catalog:

Two players control two full-color gunmen on the screen. Flashing code symbols tell you when to "shoot." But don't draw at the wrong time--your gun won't fire, and you're in for a surprise. Rated NV (Non-Violent) by the Beagle Bros staff. Try it anyway!

107948.name: Magic Pack
107948.description:
From the Beagle Bros Winter 1980-81 catalog:

Four great magic tricks in one program--

These four tricks, with a little help from you, will have them rolling on the rug. About the time they suspect that you (of all people) have something up your cuffs and have been pulling some fast ones with your Apple (which you have), you turn it over to the audience member and the computer still does the impossible!

Four tricks are included--

1. PLENTY-QUESTIONS: Think of an object; the computer asks some key questions; the computer tells you what your object is. A real cage-rattler!

2. CARD SCANNER: The computer reads cards through the TV screen. Just press any playing card against the screen and watch it work!

3. NEXTWORD: Audience members test their wits on this one. Can they figure out what the Apple is up to? Most can't. Only you know its secret.

4. 21 NUMBERS: An Apple switch on a mix-'em-up card trick that never fails!

107949.name: Slippery Digits
107949.description:
From the Beagle Bros Winter 1980-81 catalog:

Remember your old 15-numbered Whatchamacallit with the sliding numbers> Wait till you play with a computerized one! Completely keyboard controlled, Slippery Digits features full-color graphics and different degrees of difficulty complete with music signals when you are on the right track and disappearing numbers when you're not! Each level's scores are kept in memory so players can compare their skills. Not as easy as it might seem. Slippery digits is a proven winner for all ages!

107950.name: Oink! (1980)
107950.description:
From the Beagle Bros Winter 1980-81 catalog:

Pork out with Oink!--an exciting and nerve-racking dice game with unpredictable results. The tame will never win... well, not USUALLY! Sound effects, dice graphics, player names and two-key operation make this one of our most popular games!

107951.name: Buzzword
107951.description:
From the Beagle Bros Winter 1980-81 catalog:

A real laugher! Actually two games--The Apple types a story and you trigger the missing "Buzzwords"", a different one for each key OR you type a story and the Apple supplies the Buzzwords. Four stories in memory with endless possibilities, and a "create your own" program too.

107952.name: Triple Digits
107952.description:
From the Beagle Bros Winter 1980-81 catalog:

A thinker's game--easy to play but hard-as-heck to win!

Two players are given thirteen numbers each to distribute on the Triple Digits screen layout. scoring can be done in four ways, and your Apple keeps track and posts all possibilities. Plan-ahead strategy, both for scoring and for blocking is the key to winning at Triple Digits. All skill levels enjoy this one.

107953.name: Corn Game
107953.description:
From the Beagle Bros Winter 1980-81 catalog:

A great kids' guessing game that sneaks in a little math practice without them knowing it! With full color graphics of farm animals, the object is to guess how many ears of corn each animal will eat. Probability comes into play as it becomes evident who the big corn eater is.

107954.name: Hang-Person
107954.description:
From the Beagle Bros Winter 1980-81 catalog:

A beagle Bros color version of Hangman! Two ways to play:

(1) You type in a secret word, and the computer turns it into blanks for someone else to guess, or

(2) You try to guess the computer's word from over 200 he has stored (no repeats!).

107955.name: Master-Find
107955.description:
From the Beagle Bros Winter 1980-81 catalog:

Yep, you guessed it! The old classic, but with FIVE numbers! You decide how many the computer should choose from and whether or not to allow repeat numbers. Then put on your deduction cap, and figure out the Apple's secret!

107956.name: Tic Tac Fooey!
107956.description:
From the Beagle Bros Winter 1980-81 catalog:

The computer will BEAT your friends everytime if you want it to (in the CHEAT MODE, that is).

Otherwise, it's you against the computer with a winner every game thanks to our special tic-tac-tie breaker. Outfox the Apple if you can!

Total points are graphically displayed to determine the ultimate winner.

107957.name: Beagle Bros Game Pack #1
107957.description:
From the Beagle Bros 1981 catalog:

1. TextTrain: Race the on-screen clock with your text-format video "freight train." Real-time track switching & coupling simulations; hours of fun!

2. Sub Search: Find & capture the invisible enemy subs on your Apple color graphics scope! Sound-enhanced scanner, tracer and instrument panel.

3. Pick-a-Pair: A colorful Apple party game for all ages and skill levels! Uncover and remember the hidden graphics symbols to score big and win!

107958.name: Quorsum
107958.description:
Quorsum is an abstract, strategic racing game for two players. The goal is simple enough: move your tokens to the opposite corner of the 4x4 board. Quorsum is unique, however, in that the board is never the same from game to game; rather, the 16 board tiles are picked at random before the game, so that players must constantly react to an unexpected setup. Not only that, but the board continues to change throughout the game, as players try to flip key tiles from light to dark or vice versa.

Luck is minimal: even the dice require skill, since players may decide how many of their dice to use for each important move. The result is a fast-paced game in which players must constantly calculate the best path to take and the best way to hinder the opponent's tokens. Although the experienced player will usually win, still there is often a chance for both players right up until the last move.

Quorsum avoids both the predictable setup of most strategy games, and the swings of luck in most dice games. The players' fate, therefore, is always in their own hands.

107959.name: Beagle Bros Game Pack #2
107959.description:
From the Beagle Bros 1981 catalog:

1. Wowzo: Our challenging changeable maze game! Capture targets in a flexible maze, and outmaneuver your opponent before time runs out!

2. Elevators: Keyboard control 4 elevators at one time in your CRT skyscraper. You'll need a computer to solve this one!

3. Quick-Draw!: You command two colorful gunmen who shoot it out on your Apple screen!

107960.name: Beagle Bros Game Pack #3
107960.description:
From the Beagle Bros 1981 catalog:

1. Magic Pack: Four mind-bending tricks in one fantastic Magic Show! Only you and your Apple know how to perform these amazing feats!

2. Slippery Digits: A challenging & colorful number-action game for all ages. A great demonstration of your Apple's capabilities!

3. Oink!: A nerve-racking sound-enhanced video dice game with unpredictable results and lots of laughs!

107961.name: Beagle Bros Game Pack #4
107961.description:
From the Beagle Bros 1981 catalog:

1. Buzzword: A comical story-creator with endless possibilities. 5 changeable stories in memory plus a fascinating "Create Your Own Story" program!

2. Triple Digits: A thinker;s game with numbers. Score in four ways and outfox your opponent!

3. Corn Game: A kids' guessing game involving 3 farm animals and endless supply of corn!

107962.name: Menace Beach
107962.description:
User Summary

Your girlfriend Bunny has been kidnapped by infamous Demon Dan. So you pick up your skateboard and and off you go to free her. Grab anything remotely resembling a weapon you find along the way. Make short work of various villainous ninjas, clowns and dock workers trying to stop you. Save your strength as Demon Dan won't be a piece of cake.

107963.name: Metal Fighter
107963.description:
User Summary

You control MCS-920 and you are trying to escape from a planet infested with bionic alien mutants. Your only chance to succeed is to destroy the alien spaceships, defeat the fiendish alien guards, steal their bizarre weapons and, finally, overpower the grotesque alien tyrant in each level.

107965.name: Deadly Games Pack
107965.description:
User Summary

Compilation CD-ROM of the Macintosh edition of four of Deadly Games titles:


The Battle of Britain 2
Bomber
M4: Sherman Tank Simulator
U-Boat


All four games (and PDF copies of their manuals and other documentation) were collected onto a single CD-ROM. All of the games needed to be moved to the Mac's hard drive to be played.

107966.name: Operation Secret Storm
107966.description:
User Summary

You are secret agent George B. in an undercover operation in Iraq. Your task is to fight the Iraqi army and free the oil refineries. Use your fists and kicks or use the weapons dropped by the enemy. Gird yourself for serious fighting as you delve deeper and deeper into enemy territory.

107967.name: Postman Pat A Very Special Delivery Board Game
107967.description:
A simple roll and move game for the very young.

Another busy day for Postman Pat as he dashes around collecting Special Delivery parcels for the residents of Greendale. Be the first to find and collect the most matching parcels. Players spin the spinner to move around the board, depending on the number of parcels pictured on the square they landed on they get to turn over the same number of tiles in the middle of the board, if they get a matching pair they get to keep them. If they land on one of the character squares they get to jumble some of the tiles.

The publisher says this is a memory game with a jumble shuffle twist (whatever that is)!

107968.name: P'radikus Conflict
107968.description:
User Summary

P'radikus Conflict is an "Asteroids" type game where you control a spaceship trying to reach the infamous Pradicus system. As zillions of enemy vessels pit themselves against yours, you need to keep re-arming, refueling and upgrading your own. Ultimately, if you survive long enough to obtain the indispensable Toson Drive, you may succeed in halting the advance of the enemy, by destroying their planet.

107969.name: Postman Pat Mayhem at the Sorting Office Board Game
107969.description:
A simple roll and move game for the very young. Children will need a little luck to be the first to find the letters that matches the character name on their postcard. It is a nicely themed game about this popular children's TV favourite.

From the publisher;
Today is total mayhem at the sorting office! Letters are everywhere and no-one know what to do, so Pat has no choice but to stop his deliveries and help sort out the mess! Players each have a postcard belonging to a resident of Greendale, then race around the sorting office turning over the jumble of post to find the missing letters. The first to find all their missing letters from their postcard is the winner!

107970.name: TFX
107970.description:
TFX was one of the precursor combat flight simulators that helped to define the standards of modern combat flight simulators, together with Tornado, F14 Fleet Defender and the Falcon series. TFX was programmed by the British company Digital Image Design and published by Ocean Software in 1993.

At the time, TFX graphics and realism with all options on (most players missed the realism settings in the SETUP menu) were far superior to any other home computer simulator of the time and most made even years ago, so much that it brought the attention of British and Australian military, and eventually DID become involved in military projects such as the TIALD laser designator trainer.

Even though its graphics and realism were acclaimed, the player was alone in most missions, maybe because most of the players had only 386 computers at the time, and having 3 or more planes at full realism/quality being simulated in an 386 or Amiga would make the game run very slow, at around 2 frames per second. For demonstration purposes in ECTS September 1993, a 486 DX4 100 MHz was used.

Ideally it is desired to run this combat flight simulation on a 80486 based PC @ 66 MHz or higher with an SVGA PCI graphics card to obtain good video graphic frame rates. The simulation runs rather nicely in DOS mode on an Intel Pentium microprocessor based PC.

The pilot could fly 3 planes: The Eurofighter, the F-22 and the F-117. The payload for each plane could be fine-tuned by the player according to mission type.

The possible modes of play included an instant-action arcade mode, custom missions or the campaign (Tour of Duty).

The campaign mode sees you taking the role of a pilot flying for the fictional, United Nations Air Force flying missions in one of five theatres (Colombia, Somalia, Libya, the Balkans and also the South Georgia Islands). The tour of duty was designed to offer a "soap opera" approach, where actions from the players would affect the world and following missions, as well as reaction in the front page of journals according to what the player did. The Eurofighter finally flew for the United Nations for real in March 2011 as part of the UN no-fly zone enforcement in Libya.

Source: Wikipedia, "TFX (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

107971.name: QI the Board Game
boardgamepodcastepisode: Cult of the New Board Game Podcast Episode 026 – Random Top 10 Games
107971.description:
Game based on the very funny 'quiz' show. Two teams of two celebrities in each team compete to answer really obscure questions but can lead to very funny and creative answers. You score very little for getting a question right but if you make a rather obvious answer, a klaxon sounds and you gather lots of minus points. The box features host Stephen Fry on the cover. The odd name for the show, QI, stands for 'Quite Interesting'.

The publisher says;
According to The Bible what came first the chicken or the egg? Be careful with your answer. Get it right and you move forward but a wrong answer could mean the dreaded klaxon and you'll be going backwards! The answer to this and hundreds of other obscure and fascinating facts can be found in this hilarious board game based on the QI television programme!

107972.name: Scooby-Doo! and the Monster Mall Board Game
107972.description:
Game based on the characters from the animated TV show.

The publisher says;
Scooby doo and the gang have made a quick stop at the late night mall to do some last minute shopping.
Although, unknown to them, they aren't the only customers there!

Wandering around the aisles are three scary monsters who intend to make their shopping experience one they will never forget! So grab a trolley, head to the aisles, and lets do some shopping!

107973.description: This is a 2 player deck building game that has player interaction, balance, and strategy as the primary focuses. Every game turn has both players taking actions. We have defense and offense represented, so you are not just at the mercy of the cards. You do not have to add to your deck each turn, so the size of your deck is up to you, and there for you are in control of how likely you are to draw the cards you need.
107973.name: The Basketball Deck Building Game

107974.name: Shake Spell
107974.description:
A simple word game. Each player rolls the eight dice. Seven of the dice are white with a letter on each face. The eighth die is black and has a symbol on it such as a question mark. Just make a word that goes with the symbol.
The publisher describes it as a cross between Scrabble and Boggle.
The game comes in a carry case so it makes a good game to take on holiday.

107975.name: Raid 2020
107975.description:
User Summary

2020 A.D. America has become a sinister place. Morals have collapsed. Law enforcement has faltered. You are Shadow, one of the few remaining assiduous agents in this disorderly world. Your task is to defeat drug kingpin Pit Bull and it will not be an easy one. You need to fend off Pit Bull's servants and avoid a multitude of obstacles before you can face the evil druglord himself.

107976.name: The Enigma of Leonardo: Quintis Fontis
107976.description:
The Enigma of Leonardo: Quintis Fontis is a specialized version of "The Enigma of Leonardo" designed for hardcore players, for those, that considered the core version too simple. Designed for those players, that enjoy strategic planning and quick thinking.

QF is played using the same cards as the core set – each card has two symbols on it, there are 12 different symbols altogether. Most of the cards are identical to the ones in the core set, while others have different symbol combinations on them. The set also includes a few special text cards (action cards).

The goal of the game is the same as in The Enigma of Leonardo, to collect Secret Keys, by making sequences of identical symbols but this time the game is played on one big field. The field itself is made during game play, the only restriction being its size – 5x5 cards. The first card is placed in the middle of the playing field, players then take turns at playing cards, increasing the field. In the end, the first card that was played might not even be in the middle anymore, it could be on the edge.

Players can not only play cards on empty spaces, they can play cards on top of each other and can even replace cards from their hands with the ones on the playing field. The only condition is that the cards being replaced must share a common symbol. This playing mechanic allows for more complex combos, by careful planning, one can gradually replace all the cards on the field with symbols that the player needs.

Just like in The Enigma of Leonardo, in QF players receive Secret Keys when they successfully make a row of cards with the same symbol. But now you can get symbols not only for 3 cards in a row, but for four and even five identical symbols. Qunitis fontis actually means – “the fifth symbol”, when translated from Latin. Rows can be made horizontally, diagonally and vertically just like in the core game but now you can receive the same key more than once by first making a row of three symbols and then adding cards with the fourth and fifth symbol.

But it sounds much easier than it actually is. The game now uses a special counter-marker called “veto”. After playing a card, the player may choose to move the marker on any card (even the one he just played) on the playing field. The next player cannot play any cards that share a symbol with the marked card. It’s up to the players to decide should they move the marker each turn or keep it in one place blocking a certain symbol combination for the entire game.

Another new addition to QF are the action cards. There aren’t much compared to another expansion of the game The Enigma of Leonardo – Novem – but they can alter the flow of the game. With these cards you can steal symbols from your opponents and prevent them from gaining new ones.

The player who successfully collects seven Keys is the winner. If the deck is used up and no one has collected seven Keys, the one to collect the most is the winner. In case of a tie a key gradation has been provided.

QF is basically a harder version of The Enigma of Leonardo: the rules are different but the cards used are practically identical. Meaning you can try playing The Enigma of Leonardo using QF or vice versa. It will be a slightly different game, but it’s still possible.


Reimplements:

The Enigma of Leonardo

107977.name: Point Final
107977.description:
Most of the cards in this card game are letter cards, with which a word is formed; the rest are special action cards. Each player has six cards at the start of the game; the goal is to get rid of one's cards first.
The first player plays a card on the table; this card will be the first letter of a word that s/he thinks about (but doesn't say out loud). The next player adds a second letter to the word, etc. There are many jokers, so there are also many possibilities for what a word might be. When a player doubts that the last player can still think of a word starting with the letters on the table, s/he can call the bluff. If the previous players cannot produce a word, the bluffing player must pick up the cards from the table, if s/he can, the accusing player picks them up. Instead of playing a card, a player can also choose to draw a new card from the stack, but still takes responsibility for the word on the table (i.e., if called, must produce a word with these letters).
By placing a facedown card on the table, any player (out of turn order), can announce that a word is complete. The letters are then discarded and a new word is started.

There are various special cards with which players can be forced to say a word with the current letters, cards can be passed to other players, etc.

When a player plays his or her last card, the other players count the points printed on their remaining cards. These are their negative scores.

107978.name: Tip of the Tongue
107978.description:
Aimed at children, this is a game reminiscent of Taboo, where you must describe an object on the card but without using certain key words. For instance, it might say 'Balloon' and you cannot use the words 'pop’, ‘inflate’, ‘bang’ or ‘float’?

The subjects are graded so that different age groups can play.

The cards are dispensed from a yellow plastic head and the cards becomes its tongue, so to speak.

107979.description:
Manga Party comes with two copies of 26 cards (one with red back, one with beige) that each feature a scene drawn manga-style; it's up to the players to bring the party!

To set up the game, the 26 beige cards are laid face-up on the table. Three red-backed "mime" cards are shuffled with the 26 red-backed scene cards to form a deck.

On a turn, the active player draws the top card from the deck, then acts out a scene, complete with whatever thoughts, cries, declarations, etc. best fit the word bubble or thought bubble on the card. The other players race to identify which beige card matches the scene being acted out. Each player can choose only one card, and no card can be chosen more than once. If the correct card is chosen, the guesser scores the beige card and the actor keeps the red card; otherwise both scene cards are removed from the game and the actor takes the "Malus" card (whether from the table or another player).

If a player draws a Mime card, he discards it, draws the next card, and acts out the scene but without any dialogue or sounds.

The game ends when either two beige cards remain on the table or after the third Mime card has been resolved. Players scores one point per card collected, with the holder of the Malus card losing one point. The player with the most points wins.
107979.name: Manga Party

107980.name: City Fighter
107980.description:
User Summary

The city of London is under heavy attack by an alien invading force. The city's nuclear reactor must be protected at all costs! You are London's last line of defense and only hope. Your cannon is powerful enough to fend off wave after wave of attackers but... can you avoid their bombs and keep them from landing?

107981.name: Cityfighter
107981.description:
User Summary

Earth has been invaded! Everything except one remaining stronghold has been completely destroyed. You have been appointed to the task of rescuing the remaining citizens as well as obliterating the enemy. Your mega-blasters are ready. It's payback time!

107982.name: Battle of the Bulge (ZX Spectrum)
107982.description:
User Summary

December 1944. The Germans launched a massive attack at a weak point in the Allied front intending to break through the Ardennes and capture Antwerp. Feel the excitement of reliving this last ditch attempt to avert the course of the war... or die trying.

107983.name: My Little Pony Merry-Go-Round Game
107983.description:
Object: Be the first to get eight stamps on your score sheet.

Each player gets 4 cards (one for each pony) and a score sheet. Before each turn, every player chooses one card to place face-down. The player whose turn it is then spins the merry-go-round, and when it stops, one of four colors will display through the merry-go-round windows.
Anybody whose face-down card matches the color displaying through the windows may use the pony of that color to stamp his/her score sheet.

Contents:

Mechanical merry-go-round with ball top
Sheet of stickers for merry-go-round base
4 stamper pony pieces with stamp caps (Posey, Heart Throb, Cherries Jubilee, & Medley)
16 pony cards (4 of each pony)
1 pad of score sheets to stamp and color
Instruction sheet

107984.name: Depth Charge
107984.description:
Depth Charge is a game for the Apple II family of computers, created in 1978 by programmer Chris Oberth and published by The Elektrik Keyboard of Chicago, Illinois.

Like the 1977 arcade game Depthcharge that it emulates, Depth Charge puts the player in control of a small ship that drops depth charges onto passing submarines. The ship makes three passes from right to left across the top of the screen, and four submarines at varying depths move from left to right below it. Destroying deeper subs earns the player more points; one extra pass is awarded at 600 points another at 900 points. The screen inverts in overtime. Hits, misses, score and high score are displayed at the bottom of the screen.

Source: Wikipedia, "Depth Charge (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

107985.name: T.H.E. Fighter
107985.description:
User summary:

The sequel to T.H.E. Non-Player Character, this presented a whole new set of rules for Fantasy Role-Playing combat. Was adaptable to most systems of the time.

Three more modules were planned but never published.

56 pages plus 8 pages of charts and a fold out map.

107986.name: The Lost Caverns of Tsojconth
107986.description:
User summary:

The original version of what became S4: The Lost Caverns of Tsojcanth (note the different spelling of the last word). Originally written for WinterCon V by Gary Gygax.

It is estimated the print run of the module is only 300.

Counting the pages is difficult. Most accounts of this module list "8 loose leaf pages".

Well, there is the cover itself that's 11 by 17 inches, there are 4 8.5 by 11 inch sheets with typing front and back. One 8.5 by 11 sheet with 4 illustrations, each occupying a 5.5 by 8 inch space, and 6 5.5 by 8 inch single sided character sheets.

The character sheets were printed two to a page and then cut in half when used.

This is the only module by Gary Gygax that was published separately for the original version of Dungeons & Dragons.

107988.name: Cataclysm
107988.description:
Cataclysm is a large board chess variant (12 X 16)

It uses most of the basic chess pieces from FIDE chess, plus a range of additional, mostly short range pieces.

New pieces include;

Grand Rook: The Grand Rook can move as either a standard Rook, or as a Cannon from Chinese Chess (that is, it can capture an enemy piece by leaping over exactly one piece of either color and capturing the first piece beyond, if that piece is an enemy piece.)

Sorceress: The Sorceress is a 2-space area-mover. She may make either a single step in any direction as a King, or may make two consecutive steps in any direction and may change directions in between. The only limitations are that the Sorceress may not return to her original square (thereby making a null-move) and may not capture a piece on the first move and continue on - her move ends with any capture.

The Elephant may slide up to four spaces diagonally, or may step a single space horizontally or vertically. This piece has no relation to the Elephant of Shatranj.

The Tiger may slide up to four spaces horizontally or vertically, or may step a single space diagonally.

The Duke may slide up to three spaces in any direction. He moves like a Queen in Chess, except that he is limited to a range of only three squares

and others

Each player has 40 pieces (including 16 pawns)

107989.name: Echoes of the Overwatched
107989.description:
From the publisher's website:

When a Pathfinder agent working in the famed Blakros Museum in Absalom falls victim to a terrible, ancient evil, if falls to the PCs to hunt down the released terror before it can retrieve a relic of the mad astronomer Ralzeros the Overwatched.

A Pathfinder Society Scenario designed for Levels 1–5.

This scenario is designed for play in Pathfinder Society Organized Play, but can easily be adapted for use with any world. This scenario is compliant with the Open Game License (OGL) and is suitable for use with the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game.

107990.name: Among the Gods
107990.description:
From the publisher's website:

The Pathfinder Society sends the PCs to the mountaintop mausoleum and monument known as Antios's Crown in search of a long-lost relic believed to be contained there, but all is not as it seems. Can the Pathfinders survive the denizens of the remote mountain complex and the sinister plot of a powerful cultists who plans revenge on the Society that has foiled his plans one too many times?

A Pathfinder Society Scenario designed for Levels 3–7.

This scenario is designed for play in Pathfinder Society Organized Play, but can easily be adapted for use with any world. This scenario is compliant with the Open Game License (OGL) and is suitable for use with the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game.

107991.name: The Edge of Heaven
107991.description:
From the publisher's website:

In the distant land of Tian Xia, the Pathfinder Society's Lantern Lodge sends a team of agents high into the Wall of Heaven Mountains to an abandoned Iroran monastery in search of a powerful relic to assist them in ensure victory in the upcoming Ruby Phoenix Tournament. Though the monastery has long laid unused by the faithful of the Master of Masters, it is not completely devoid of danger, and the PCs soon discover that merely retrieving the ancient artifact is but the beginning of a much larger quest.

The Edge of Heaven is the first scenario in the three-part The Quest for Perfection campaign arc. It is followed by Pathfinder Society Scenario #3-11: The Quest for Perfection - Part II: On Hostile Waters and Pathfinder Society Scenario #3-13: The Quest for Perfection - Part III: Defenders of Nesting Swallow. All three chapters are intended to be played in order.

A Pathfinder Society Scenario designed for Levels 1–5.

This scenario is designed for play in Pathfinder Society Organized Play, but can easily be adapted for use with any world. This scenario is compliant with the Open Game License (OGL) and is suitable for use with the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game.

107992.name: The Immortal Conundrum
107992.description:
From the publisher's website:

In an effort to learn more about the infamous sun orchid elixir of desert-laden Thuvia and past bidders in the annual auction to procure a dose, the Decemvirate sends a team of Pathfinders to a social gathering held by the guardian of this year's six doses. Can the PCs navigate the complex social landscape of Absalom's elite and gain access to the mysterious vault known as the Conundrum, or will they face public ridicule or worse in the face of the steepest competition in the Inner Sea?

A Pathfinder Society Scenario designed for Levels 5–9.

This scenario is designed for play in Pathfinder Society Organized Play, but can easily be adapted for use with any world. This scenario is compliant with the Open Game License (OGL) and is suitable for use with the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game.

107994.name: Die Katakomben des Nekromanten
107994.description:
From the back of the book:

"Death in the Dreiental
The dog tears at its leash while pulling you over the top of the next hill. The traces you are following have long disappeared, but the animal is still following the scent and leading you deeper and deeper into the scant mountinous landscape.
Upon finally reaching a canyon from which the wind howls ceaselessly, the dog's panting turns into a fearful yelp as an unnatural cold grips your hearts...

The heroes stand before the portal of the old necropolis Morrdakar, the midday sun gleaming on the notched blades of the undead skeletons awaiting you motionless at the entrance.
In the catacombs beyond lurk the necromancer Azan Al'Azzrak, master of the dark arts, the shrewd warriors of a hobgoblin tribe, and the wild henchmen of an ork tribe. Diplomacy, resourcefulness and mastery of the blade are necessary to survive the dangers of this dungeon and to prevent the resurrection of the mighty dragon Duesterzahn.
The fate of the Dreiental - and more - rests on the shoulders of the heroes...

"Die Katakomben des Nekromanten" ("The Catacombs of the Necromancer") is an Dungeonslayers adventure for 5th- to 8th-level characters taking place in the Dreiental of the Free Lands. It can be used in connection with "Die Minen von Crimlak" ("The Mines of Crimlak") or standalone.

Additional User summary:
Part 2 of 3 of the Dreiental Trilogy, with Part 3 "Der Kult des Roten Drachen" ("The Cult of the Red Dragon") announced on the final page.

107995.name: Silent Assault
107995.description:
User Summary

Earth has been taken over by aliens! All military forces are under their complete control... except you. The last vestiges of Earth's defenses are still under your control and you must make prudent use of them. You will have to engage enemy forces, both alien and domestic. You will have ample opportunities to upgrade your firepower, but you must avoid coming into contact with aliens and/or enemy bullets. All is not lost. You have eight levels to prove it.

107996.description:
A spin-off from the popular Lost World Combat Book series. Instead of fantasy heroes, the players take the roles of fighting Dinosaurs.

Each player neeeds a booklet to play. Booklets are traded and, as each player selects a move, a reference grid determines the result (wounds loss, off balance maneuvers, and so on). Combat continues until one Dinosaur or the other expires.
107996.name: Lost Worlds Dino Fight Series

107997.name: Combat Mission: Shock Force – Marines
107997.description:
An expansion, called Combat Mission: Shock Force - Marines was released on 26 September 2008 and marketed by direct sale through Battlefront's website, requiring Combat Mission: Shock Force to play. The module was sold by direct download, physical disc, or both, and included the latest patch for the Shock Force base game, which was also made available via free download to all non-Marines customers and works without the module for owners of the base game. Content of Marines include an increased number of units, 15 standalone scenarios, an 18-mission campaign, and 25 new Quick Battle maps. New units represent United States Marine Corps and Syrian Airborne troops, as well as regular Syrian units such as the T-90 tank.

Source: Wikipedia, "Combat Mission: Shock Force", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

107998.description:
This expansion is made of 10 (36 cards total) of the building cards BGGers suggested in this GeekList, and the ones that got most votes went to the Finalist Round.

Keeping in mind the results of the round, the Cambridge Games Factory employees chose what cards to keep. They were then helped by some BGGers in playtesting/tweaking them and the final results are here.

This Promo expansion was reserved to the Kickstarters supporters of the Black Box Edition, but it's not excluded that there will be wider print runs.
The expansion was printed in two versions, one with Ed Carter's cartooney artwork and the other using Heiko Günther's essential style.

One note on compatibility: The expansion cards created with the original artwork are 63 mm x 88 mm. The 2007 printing of GtR I.V had cards that were 64.5 mm x 89.5 mm. If you sleeve your cards or have a later printing (which is the most common edition of I.V), then the promo cards will work fine. If not, you will find that the size of the cards is slightly mismatched.
boardgameversion: Cambridge Games Factory New Art first edition

107999.name: Combat Mission: Shock Force – NATO
107999.description:
A third expansion module for the game was announced on 13 May 2010. This module will feature NATO and Coalition forces, specifically the German, Canadian and Dutch armies.

108000.name: Combat Mission: Shock Force – British Forces
108000.description:
A second expansion module was released in August 2009, bringing the British Armed Forces to the Syrian battlefield. This new module introduces units, vehicles and weapons currently in service with the British military, such as the Challenger 2 tank and Warrior IFV, and also includes the US IBCT. There is a new campaign from the British perspective, and new standalone scenarios. There are minor changes to the Syrian side, and the expansion patches the base game to version 1.20.

Source: Wikipedia, "Combat Mission: Shock Force", available under the CC-BY-SA License.
